newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU says Boeing row strengthens case for WTO role.
newsitem.headline: EU says Boeing row strengthens case for WTO role.

text.p: European Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan said on Thursday that the row over the Boeing -McDonnell Douglas merger strengthened the case for the World Trade Organisation to be involved in anti-trust cases.
"I have long believed that we need an international agreement on competition rules and smoother cooperation between national competition jurisdictions," he said in a statement.
"There are bound to be more and more clashes when powerful competition authorities seek to deal with the same case, applying different rules."

The European Commission on Wednesday approved in principle a merger between the two U.S. aircraft manufacturers after Boeing agreed to last-minute concessions aimed at ensuring the company would not abuse its strong market position and would leave airlines the choice of buying rival planes.
The proposed merger sparked a furious transatlantic trade row with U.S. politicians saying the Commission had no right to block what was effectively an American affair.
The Commission argued that because the merger would leave the new company with a dominant market share in Europe, it had to intervene.
"We have avoided a crisis this time but this is a problem that will not go away until there is an effective international agreement on the application of competition rules," said Brittan.
A ministerial meeting of the WTO in Singapore in December established a working group to look at trade and competition policy, but the committee has met only once since then.

"Major mergers such as the Boeing-Mcdonnell Douglas ... inevitably arouse concern in several countries around the world.," Brittan said. "Once again we have reached an amicable conclusion, but it is never easy. We need better safeguards against unnecessary conflict of interest. -- David Fox, Brussels Newsroom ++32 2 287 6832
